data.title: Nvidia Is Untouchable For 2026
data.description:
NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) continues to benefit from the global excitement around artificial intelligence, experiencing strong demand for its GPU and networking solutions. The strong data center build-out provides half a trillion dollars in revenue visibility, propelling the stock price more than 50% since the beginning of the year. Nvidia has crossed the $5 trillion valuation mark amidst the growing fears for the AI bubble. And while the bubble concerns were confirmed by some industry leaders, I believe that Nvidia is not associated with it. The company has the potential to grow at least at a 30% angle, while the valuation has climbed to its fair value since my previous coverage. Although the industry signals are strengthening with big tech’s approaching $100 billion in quarterly investments, my conservative growth scenario indicates 25% upside potential.

FY2026 is an Nvidia year

With the rapid proliferation of artificial intelligence in the recent year, Nvidia has experienced a surge in demand for its GPU solutions, allowing the company to showcase impressive rates of financial growth. The stock price is up by 50% since the beginning of the year, significantly outperforming the technology sector and the broad market.

NVDA is also up 92% since my previous writing, as the company rebounded significantly from the setback caused by export constraints on AI chips to China and the tariff policies. Since then, the solid data center investment pipeline has pushed NVDA to become the world’s most valuable company. Apart from that, the AI frenzy is fueling the market bubble fears due to the circular large-scale investments between the main AI players. And because of the long-term nature of the investment plans, there will always be skepticism about how many of those investments will break ground. In my view, the three-year horizon is quite a long-term period, as the dynamics of the trade disputes and geopolitical tensions cannot be really predicted.

However, let’s take a look at the current supply chain stance. TSMC projected mid-30% revenue growth due to the accelerating demand for AI and HPC chips from hyperscalers and AI-accelerator customers. The utilization of the leading-edge node is expected to be very high as the demand is surging. At the same time, the HBM supply is shaping up to be tight, with SK hynix Inc. (OTCPK:HXSCF) hinting at a sellout of its 2026 production capacity and AI-related demand squeezing out DDR5 capacity.

Another bottleneck spot is packaging, which is becoming increasingly important for the latest generation of AI chips. In addition, Amkor increased its total investments for the new advanced packaging and test campus in Arizona up to $7 billion. Going further, Vertiv Holdings Co (VRT) reported surging orders and a robust backlog due to the strong AI-driven demand for digital infrastructure solutions such as power management, cooling systems and integrated data center platforms. Overall, the demand is prominently outstripping supply, and Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) forecasts show a data center crunch persisting into 2026 as well.

But apart from the AI bubble, the competitive landscape is rising over. Besides the ASICs' collusions, Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (AMD) is progressing to be the most fearful alternative with a full-stack Helios rack-scale AI platform, which is believed to be on par with Vera Rubin. Both systems feature 72 GPUs onboard and are expected to enter mass production in the back half of 2026. Now, let’s recall AMD’s $500 billion data center AI accelerator TAM estimate in 2028. The figure now seems more than viable given the fact that big tech is expected to dedicate more than $344 billion this year.

The capital investments are growing at an impressive pace, with quarterly Capex from Meta, Google, Amazon, and Microsoft approaching the $100 billion level combined. On the other hand, another forecast from Citi is pointing to $490 billion in AI Capex across the hyperscalers already in 2026 and a total of $2.8 trillion through 2029. And while I used to take the projections made by Nvidia’s executives with a grain of salt, the $3-4 trillion in AI infrastructure spending by the end of the decade seems reasonable.

But let’s stick to the $500 billion AI accelerator market size scenario, which is still a significant jump compared to some $130 billion in 2024. If we suppose that Nvidia would maintain around 60% market share, it suggests up to $300 billion in revenue from the data center segment in 2028, or circa 30% CAGR. Despite growing by 56% YoY in the second fiscal quarter of 2025, the company will come down to such a growth dynamic at some point.

Nonetheless, this projection is far more conservative compared to Jensen Huang’s visibility into half a trillion in sales for Grace Blackwell and Vera Rubin through 2026. This figure most likely includes the partnership with OpenAI (OPENAI) to deploy at least 10 gigawatts of Nvidia AI systems. Indeed, with the rollout of Blackwell Ultra systems, Nvidia is going to dominate the market in 2026 as well. However, we should discern the visibility from when this revenue is actually going to be recognized. And even if AMD comes up with a superior rack-scale platform, the point is that such a big market share is not going to dissipate any time soon. Because, as I wrote in my latest piece on AMD, the main advantage of Nvidia is in the timing between architectural generations. AMD opted for a new process technology for its MI350 series, which took time for the transition to the 3nm lithography.

On the other hand, Nvidia switched to a double-die package, effectively doubling the performance of the Hopper generation while staying at the same process node. Moreover, Nvidia is planning to shift its roadmap to only an eight-month gap in production ramp-up, which could be highly beneficial, especially when the market for AI systems continues to be supply chain-restricted.

Reversion angle

Against the backdrop of the AI bubble fears, it’s hard to believe that a company worth nearly $5 trillion with a 50% stock price gain since the beginning of the year is fairly valued. I used to mention that a 30% growth reversion angle could bring the valuation of NVDA stock down to the low 20x in FY2028. Apparently, it went so much faster due to the rapid expansion of data center build-outs. And looking at the chart now, the company is trading at 33.4x forward P/E, which is slightly below the 3-year median of 33.6x.

*The two dotted lines represent one standard deviation above and below the median line.

So, we can see that NVDA stock is clearly valued at its fair level, climbing from the bottom line of one standard deviation below the median from the time of my last piece. Basically, when you have a stock with the potential to grow at least by 30% and trading at a 30x multiple, it’s a good indication of a reasonable investment. I could confirm this with the following chart, which highlights that the earnings vector used moves in sync with the price performance dynamic.

Going forward, I prefer to stick with a 30% growth angle to form a more conservative scenario. I believe that NVDA stock has room for 30% multiple expansions for the next 12-month horizon, or up to 43x forward P/E ratio. Given the analyst forecast of $6.02 EPS next year, this indicates a $261 value per share, which stipulates a 25% upside potential.

Investment takeaways

With superior computing power and deep optimization, Nvidia accelerators deliver the world's highest performance for AI workloads, benefiting from the NVLink technology. Apart from that, the company develops high-performance networking (InfiniBand and Spectrum-X) solutions that enable the interconnection of large-scale clusters, which is especially relevant when we are talking about data center projects in gigawatt measure. The CUDA software stack is another strength, which has effectively become the industry standard, enabling the adaptation of GPUs to solve a wide range of computational tasks. These three pillars help Nvidia to retain customers in its ecosystem, due to the lack of meaningful substitution offerings, at least until the end of 2026.

Apart from that, Nvidia is continuously teaming up with industry leaders to ensure its technology remains at the forefront amid the AI revolution. The scope of investment into data center build-outs is constantly growing, representing a strong growth potential visibility. The demand signals make tech giants spend relentlessly on artificial intelligence, with Microsoft planning to double its data center footprint over the next 2 years, Meta signaling a strong Capex expansion, and Alphabet approaching $100 billion in investments for the year.

Hence, I believe that NVDA deserves a Buy recommendation even at a $5 trillion market cap. It remains to be seen how much of that revenue visibility mentioned at the GTC will even be recognized in the following five quarters. But definitely, Nvidia has the potential to grow at least by 30% in the near term, which, against the backdrop of a low 30s valuation multiple, looks like a good entry point. And even with a conservative expectation for TAM potential, NVDA stock still has 25% upside for the next 12-month horizon.

data.title: Toyota's Sixth-Gen RAV4 Symbolizes Electrification's Gradual Arrival
data.description:
Toyota Motor (TM) notched a significant milestone in 2024 when the RAV4 compact SUV, in its fifth generation, became the single best-selling vehicle model of any kind in the U.S., surpassing the Ford F150 pickup truck, a model that has dominated sales charts for decades.

The sixth-generation RAV4 soon will be available in U.S. Toyota dealerships, offering enhancements and features that likely will establish the model as a top seller for at least the near future. RAV4’s sales leadership in the U.S.—the world's most profitable vehicle market—is topping on the cake for the Japanese automaker, the No. 1 automaker worldwide in terms of unit sales.

According to the Toyota newsroom, prices for the new model will start in the low $30,000 range and rise to about $50,000 for the best-equipped versions.

The new RAV4—available only as a gas-electric hybrid or plug-in hybrid—exemplifies Toyota’s determination to electrify its product line gradually and along multiple pathways, rather than swiftly with battery electric vehicles (BEVs), a strategy that has drawn criticism from environmental activists and others who argue in favor of rapid migration to BEVs.

Toyota has argued that the limited worldwide capacity and resources for manufacturing batteries, inadequate charging infrastructure, and consumer hesitancy to switch to BEVs from internal combustion engines (especially in the U.S.) dictate a more deliberate and gradual move to BEVs over a longer period of time, perhaps many years. Ultimately, Toyota says, the overall reduction of so-called greenhouse gases will be greater under this strategy—while preserving the company’s financial health.

Meanwhile, automakers, including General Motors Co. (GM) and Ford Motor Co. (F), have booked massive losses, worker layoffs, and write-offs—with more to come—due to slow consumer acceptance of their first BEV models. Outside of China, where BEVs may be heavily subsidized and encouraged, automakers are now introducing BEVs more slowly.

Governments, too, are rethinking policies meant to incentivize BEVs.

Seamless technology

In truth, many buyers will be unaware that their 2026 RAV4 is powered by a combination of a gasoline engine and a battery-powered electric motor; the system smoothly and quietly (according to this writer’s experience during a test drive) produces an average fuel efficiency of up to 44 miles to the gallon, combined city and highway, according to Toyota’s estimate. The RAV4’s battery receives charge from the engine, meaning that it doesn’t need external charging.

A second RAV4 version, the plug-in hybrid, has a larger battery than the standard gas-electric and must be charged; it offers an emission-free, electric-only range of about 52 miles before the gasoline engine kicks in to power the vehicle in hybrid mode. The plug-in may be operated without charging as well, and can be driven in gas-electric hybrid mode exclusively.

Toyota says the new RAV4 will be the first of its product line to feature the newest version of the Toyota Auto Multimedia system, which offers “faster, more responsive voice assistant; a new customizable home menu; and Toyota's first application of onboard 5G connectivity.” Toyota had been criticized for earlier infotainment systems that excluded Apple CarPlay and Android systems; the automaker has since changed course and allowed its system to be more easily paired and synced with smartphones.

While Toyota builds a majority of its vehicles in North America, those imported from Canada and Mexico have been subject to the administration’s tariffs. The new RAV4 will be built primarily in Georgetown, Ky., and Cambridge, Ontario, with some models imported from Japan. Accordingly, Toyota in August said its operating profit for the fiscal year ended March 30 is estimated to be reduced to $21.7 billion, or 16.3%, from its prior forecast.

Toyota shares shrugged off the guidance, rising about 15% since then while outperforming major market indices.

Rising taxes

Nevertheless, tariffs remain a major stumbling block in front of earnings growth. Toyota has formulated a response, however, which was outlined earlier this month by Seeking Alpha analyst James Hires earlier this month. Bolstered by its vaunted financial strength, the automaker has elected to absorb a significant portion of the tariff burden by limiting price hikes that it otherwise might have taken. Last June, Toyota evidently increased prices by a smaller margin than those of competitors, thus improving its value proposition, which should help to drive sales.

Additionally, Toyota has told U.S. trade officials it is looking to export U.S.-made models to Japan, a move designed to “appease” the U.S. administration and help redress the trade deficit with Japan, which was about $70 billion in 2024.

At the Tokyo Mobility Show this week, the automaker took the wraps off a BEV concept of the next-gen Corolla compact sedan, the best-selling model in its history, with more than 55 million manufactured since the nameplate was introduced in 1966. The show car attracted rave reviews from journalists, one of whom said it was “seriously cool.” While it wasn’t clear when the production version of the Corolla would be introduced, Japanese carmakers usually don’t wait long after the concept is revealed.

Reports on the new Corolla say it will have more interior space, made possible by a new generation of engines that are more compact and powerful than current models. The model may accommodate batteries, hybrids, or possibly alternative fuels.

“The Corolla is a global car, so it has to meet different powertrain requirements in different regions,” Chief Engineer Toru Fukushima told Automotive News at a pre-show briefing.

Bullish on TM ADRs

My bullish investment thesis is based on a number of core factors, some of which are reflected in the new RAV4. First of all is operating discipline, which reflects a relentless pursuit of researching those traits and features in a vehicle that consumers prioritize and delivering them in an affordable package.

A second key factor is what has proven to be a shrewd strategic direction with regard to electrification, that's a gradual migration toward zero emission that currently emphasizes gas-electric hybrid powertrains—exemplified by the decision to offer the latest RAV4 as an all-hybrid product. Since the 1990s, when the first gas-electric hybrid was introduced in Toyota Prius, the company has been improving, tweaking, and optimizing its Hybrid Synergy Drive, while many of its competitors—now to their disadvantage—bypassed the technology or deemed it of secondary importance.

Additionally, the automaker’s policy of investing in the development of multiple propulsion pathways—such as plug-in hybrids, hydrogen, batteries, as well as internal combustion—enables Toyota to commercialize its models in a multitude of global markets and for different consumer groups.

Toyota’s strong financial position, the result of generations of conservative management, provides ample resources for future investment in cutting-edge technologies such as solid-state batteries and self-driving, as well as consistent dividend payments.

Two major risk factors to this investment thesis must be mentioned: The first is new and formidable competition from the Chinese auto industry, which increasingly demonstrates its mettle with Western consumers in foreign markets as well as China and could enter the U.S. at some future date, despite the current tariff roadblock.

Finally, Toyota faces the same risk as any automaker, that negative economic conditions will dampen demand for vehicles, thus undermining the growth of revenue and profit.

Toyota ADRs remain a buy in my judgment.

data.title: My Top 10 High-Yield Picks For November 2025: One Yields 9%+
data.description:
Investment Thesis

The investment approach of The Dividend Income Accelerator Portfolio and my personal portfolio is characterized by a focus on companies that pay sustainable dividends, have significant competitive advantages, and are financially robust.

Investing in dividend-paying companies with sustainable cash flows not only allows you to increase the dividend payments on an annual basis but also to invest with a margin of safety and to increase the probability of delivering positive investment outcomes when investing over the long term.

While some of the selected companies are particularly attractive due to their ability to provide an attractive amount of dividend income and to reduce portfolio volatility (such as Verizon (VZ), Altria (MO), and Ares Capital (ARCC)), some of the selected companies blend income with dividend growth (such as Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft (OTCPK:MURGY), Principal Financial Group (NASDAQ:PFG), Iberdrola (OTCPK:IBDSF), Merck & Co (MRK), and Bank of Montreal (BMO)).

Companies such as Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft, Iberdrola, and Bank of Montreal also help you increase the global diversification of your portfolio, which further reduces your portfolio's risk level.

The companies that have been selected for today's article needed to fulfill the below pre-requirements:

  • Market Capitalization > $10 billion
  • Dividend Yield [FWD] > 3%
  • 5-Year Dividend Growth Rate [CAGR] > 1.5%.
  • P/E [FWD] ratio < 30

For November 2025, I have selected the below high-yield dividend companies:

  • Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft
  • Iberdrola
  • Merck & Co
  • CVS Health (CVS)
  • Chevron (CVX)
  • Verizon
  • Ares Capital
  • Principal Financial Group
  • Bank of Montreal
  • Altria

1. Principal Financial Group

Principal Financial Group was founded in 1879. The company operates within the Life and Health Insurance Industry.

Principal Financial Group is characterized by a dividend yield [FWD] of 3.93% and offers significant dividend growth potential. The company's dividend growth potential is reflected in its low payout ratio of 38.59% and its EPS FWD Long-Term Growth Rate [3-5Y CAGR] of 12.73%.

The table below shows the consensus dividend estimates for Principal Financial Group. For 2025, the consensus yield is at 3.88%, for 2026, at 4.12%, and for 2027, at 4.30%.

These numbers support my view that the company can be an attractive choice to blend both income and dividend growth, which makes the company also a potential candidate for our dividend portfolio.

2. Bank of Montreal

Bank of Montreal is a Canadian bank that was founded in 1817 and which currently has a market capitalization of $89.77 billion.

The bank currently offers a dividend yield [FWD] of 3.71%, while it has relatively attractive dividend growth potential. The bank's dividend growth potential is reflected in its EPS FWD Long-Term Growth Rate [3-5Y CAGR] of 16.10% and its 10-Year dividend growth rate [CAGR] of 5.62%.

In addition to the above, Bank of Montreal has an attractive positioning according to the Seeking Alpha Quant Ranking. The bank is presently placed 14th out of 65 in the Diversified Banks Industry, and ranked 60th out of 685 within the Financials Sector. In the Seeking Alpha Overall Quant Ranking, Bank of Montreal is presently positioned 265th out of 4320.

Compared to U.S. competitors such as JPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) or Citigroup (C), Bank of Montreal pays the higher dividend yield.

While Bank of Montreal's dividend yield [FWD] stands at 3.71%, JPMorgan's is at 2.02%, Bank of America's at 2.17%, and Citigroup's at 2.44%. This indicates that the Canadian bank could be the superior choice for those who focus on dividend income.

However, Bank of Montreal has a significantly higher payout ratio when compared to its U.S. peers, which indicates less potential for dividend growth: While Bank of Montreal's payout ratio stands at 59.56%, JPMorgan's stands at 27.88%, Bank of America's at 28.88%, and Citigroup's at 29.96%. These metrics show that the U.S. peers seem to be the superior choice for investors who prioritize dividend growth over current income.

3. Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft

The Munich-based company operates in the insurance and reinsurance industry. Münchener Rückversicherungs-Gesellschaft has a current market capitalization of $81.84 billion.

Today, the company pays a dividend yield [FWD] of 3.56% while it offers investors modest dividend growth potential. This is reflected in the company's relatively low payout ratio of 52.19% and its 10-Year dividend growth rate [CAGR] of 10.46%, as well as its EPS FWD Long-Term Growth Rate [3-5Y CAGR] of 3.52%.

The German company is presently placed 2nd out of 9 within the Reinsurance Industry, and ranked 41st out of 685 within the Financials Sector.

In the Seeking Alpha Overall Quant Ranking, the company is positioned 201 out of 4320.

4. Iberdrola

Iberdrola was founded in 1840 and is based in Bilbao (Spain). The company operates within the Electric Utilities Industry and presently offers investors a dividend yield [FWD] of 4.80%.

Iberdrola not only provides potential for dividend income, but also for dividend growth, which is reflected in its EPS FWD Long-Term Growth Rate [3-5Y CAGR] of 7.33% and its 3-Year dividend growth rate [CAGR] of 15.22%, making it also a candidate for potential inclusion in our dividend portfolio.

The company's P/E GAAP [FWD] Ratio is at 16.67, which is significantly below the sector median of 20.12, demonstrating that Iberdrola is currently undervalued.

5. CVS Health

CVS Health presently offers investors a free cash flow yield [TTM] of 4.56%. This implies that the company's stock price is not a result of particularly high-growth expectations, allowing investors to invest with a margin of safety.

The company's attractive valuation is also reflected in its P/E GAAP [FWD] ratio of 21.29, which is 14.53% below the Sector Median.

CVS Health's dividend yield [FWD] is presently at 3.20%. The company's payout ratio of 41.96% and its 5-Year dividend growth rate [CAGR] of 5.87% indicate room for future dividend enhancements.

The Seeking Alpha Dividend Grades underline CVS Health's solid dividend. CVS Health receives an A- rating for dividend yield, a B+ rating for dividend safety, a B rating for dividend consistency, and a C- rating for dividend growth.

6. Merck & Co

Merck is also among these types of companies that offer investors both income and dividend growth potential, aligning with the investment strategy of The Dividend Income Accelerator Portfolio.

Merck presently pays a dividend yield [FWD] of 3.70%, while its payout ratio stands at 41.36%. The company's potential for dividend growth is further underlined by its 14 consecutive years of dividend growth and its 5-Year dividend growth rate [CAGR] of 6.85%.

In addition to that, it is worth highlighting the company's attractive valuation, which is reflected in its P/E GAAP [FWD] ratio of 11.38, which stands 54.30% below the sector median and 58.87% below the company's 5-Year Average. This indicates that Merck & Co is presently undervalued.

7. Verizon

With 21 consecutive years of dividend growth, a current dividend yield [FWD] of 6.85%, and a payout ratio of 57.66%, Verizon offers investors an attractive income for today with modest dividend growth potential.

Additionally, with a current P/E [FWD] ratio of 8.77 (which stands 53.73% below the sector median), the company provides investors an attractive valuation and a margin of safety when investing.

In addition to the above, it can be highlighted that Verizon's particularly high free cash flow yield [TTM] of 11.52%, which stands significantly above the sector median of 8.01%, allows the company to pay an attractive and sustainable amount of dividends.

8. Altria

Altria presently offers investors a free cash flow yield [TTM] of 8.09%. This number indicates that investors can benefit from an investment in Altria even if the company were unable to significantly increase their earnings in the coming years.

At the company's present price level, Altria pays a dividend yield [FWD] of 6.65%, which I consider to be sustainable, particularly when considering the company's previously mentioned free cash flow yield.

Altria's EBIT margin [TTM] presently stands at 60.63%, which is an indicator of the company's excellent competitive position within its industry from which investors can benefit when investing over the long term.

9. Ares Capital

According to Wall Street, Ares Capital is currently a "Buy," receiving a "Strong Buy" rating from nine analysts, and a "Buy" rating from four analysts. Ares Capital presently gets a "Hold" rating from only two analysts.

Ares Capital currently pays a dividend yield [FWD] of 9.64%. The company has shown 20 consecutive years of dividend payments, which underlines its consistent dividend growth trajectory.

10. Chevron

At the company's current price level, Chevron offers investors an attractive free cash flow yield [TTM] of 5.95%.

Chevron's dividend yield [FWD] of 4.45%, in combination with its EPS FWD Long-Term Growth Rate [3-5Y CAGR] of 9.70%, are metrics that indicate that investors can blend both income and potential for dividend growth when investing in the company.

According to Wall Street, Chevron is presently a buy. 10 analysts rate the company as a strong buy, five as a buy, and 11 as a hold. Only from one analyst does Chevron receive a "Strong Sell" rating.

Compared to competitors such as Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Shell (SHEL), Chevron pays the higher dividend yield [FWD]. While Chevron's dividend yield is 4.45%, Exxon Mobil's is 3.51%, and Shell's is 3.94%.

Furthermore, Chevron has the longer dividend growth trajectory. Chevron has delivered 37 consecutive years of dividend growth compared to Exxon Mobil's 26 years and Shell's 3 years.

Conclusion

The investment strategy of both The Dividend Income Accelerator Portfolio and my private investment portfolio is based on a strategic balance between dividend income and dividend growth: while the first has a stronger focus on dividend income, the second prioritizes dividend growth.

What all the selected companies have in common is their capacity to provide investors with sustainable dividend income, which not only allows investors to constantly raise their dividend income but also to increase the probability of delivering strong investment outcomes when investing over the long term.

This is the case because over the long term, the companies' stock prices will follow the earnings results of the respective companies. This is the reason why the investment horizon of my portfolios is over the long term and why I suggest investing in companies that pay sustainable dividend income and that have significant competitive advantages.

Author's Note: Which high-yield dividend-paying companies are the core positions of your investment portfolio?

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Airbnb Earnings Preview: Q3 Management Commentary Will Reveal Growth Potential
data.description:
Not all investments go according to plan. When I first turned bullish on Airbnb, Inc. (ABNB) in September 2021, I was banking on the post-pandemic travel boom to drive revenue and earnings growth higher. Although this expectation has indeed materialized, in hindsight, it is evident that Mr. Market had already priced this into the company's valuation. Since my first buy call, ABNB stock is down ~21%, which is not a pleasant sight given how the S&P 500 has delivered stellar returns during the same period. I, of course, invested in ABNB as the stock retreated so my cost is around $125 per share today, and I am hardly at the breakeven point today.

With Airbnb expected to release Q3 earnings on November 6, exactly from a week from this writing, I wanted to take a step back to evaluate why the stock has gone nowhere for several years despite robust earnings growth (from a loss of $352 million in 2021, Airbnb has come a long way to report a profit of $2.63 billion in the past 12 months). What I found was that I had been too early to bet on the company's diversification efforts. In many of my follow-up articles since the initial buy call, which you can find here and here, I discussed why I thought Airbnb's growth would accelerate as the company expands into ancillary services similar to how Booking Holdings Inc. (BKNG) did. This is what I got wrong in the past 4+ years. Airbnb could never execute this strategy to perfection, and what we saw was a deceleration in revenue growth, which spooked Mr. Market.

Exhibit 1: Airbnb annual revenue growth

While growth decelerated, Airbnb shifted its focus to improving profitability. This is not a bad outcome, of course, but the market was not willing to reward Airbnb with premium valuation multiples while growth moderated, rightly so. Sooner rather than later, you want high-growth companies to turn profitable but not at the cost of growth. Airbnb has turned into a cash flow machine (TTM FCF of $4.28 billion). Some of these cash flows have been used to return capital to shareholders as well (TTM stock repurchases worth $3.7 billion).

These are all signs of a business that is growing profitably, but without an acceleration in revenue growth, I believe ABNB stock will trade sideways for the foreseeable future. This is why, in my opinion, the upcoming Q3 report will be a pivotal moment for ABNB as the management is expected to reveal the progress of the Airbnb Services business that was launched last May along with the redesign of the Experiences platform, provide new numbers to evaluate the growth in expansion markets, and also give color on the progress of integrating hotel booking into the Airbnb app.

Look Beyond Just Headline Numbers To Assess Airbnb's Growth Potential

Airbnb is expected to report $2.32 in EPS for Q3 on revenue of $4.08 billion. The company has topped analyst expectations for EPS on each of the past 3 quarters, but as illustrated below, the magnitude of these surprises has been well below the average seen in 2022 and 2023.

Exhibit 2: Airbnb earnings surprise history

Although an earnings surprise (or the lack of it) could indeed move ABNB stock in post-earnings trading, as a long-term-oriented investor, I am more interested in deciphering whether Airbnb's growth is likely to accelerate in the foreseeable future or remain under pressure.

In my opinion, a reacceleration in growth hinges on three important factors.

In the short to medium term, whether we see an acceleration of revenue growth will be largely determined by the success of Airbnb's international expansion plans. In Q2, the management revealed that Airbnb's expansion markets (the likes of Japan and Brazil) are seeing much faster growth in nights booked compared to its core markets (U.S., UK, Canada, etc.). Commenting on the fast growth observed in expansion markets, CEO Brian Chesky wrote:

For six consecutive quarters, nights booked on an origin basis in our expansion markets have grown at about twice the rate of our core markets. This sustained growth is a result of our focus on achieving product-market fit, increasing brand awareness, and driving traffic in key countries.

Later in the shareholder letter, CEO Chesky revealed that both demand and supply in expansion markets grew at more than double the pace at which they grew in core markets in Q2. When Airbnb reports Q3 earnings next week, I will be paying close attention to these metrics to see if this trend continues in the third quarter as well. Given that Airbnb's core markets are seeing a moderation in growth, expansion markets hold the key to driving overall profitability and revenue growth higher in the next 4-6 quarters.

Airbnb's focus on expansion markets seems timely given that industry experts project these markets to grow at a faster clip than well-established core markets. Boston Consulting Group expects to see the biggest gains in countries such as China, India, and Vietnam in the next 12 months.

Exhibit 3: Leisure trip destinations booked in the past 12 months and expectations for growth

As long as we are seeing continued growth in nights booked in expansion markets, I would be comfortable with my ABNB investment as I believe this would buy the company sufficient time to invest in two other growth engines—hotels and services.

When we expand our timeline from the next 4 quarters to the next 2 years, I believe the most important growth driver will be Airbnb's hotel push. Back in 2019, Airbnb acquired HotelTonight to expand into the hotel booking sector. However, until recently, we did not see an aggressive push by the company to take market share from industry leaders in this space. That is changing now. Airbnb is now planning to add a new hotel interface into its app, finally delivering on its 2019 promise to directly compete with industry leaders in this space such as Booking.com. Speaking at the Skift Global Forum last month, CEO Chesky said:

The concrete thing is we are now getting serious about hotels. We bought HotelTonight. We always had intended to integrate it into Airbnb. Then the pandemic hit, and similar to Experiences, we put everything on hold.

Commenting further on this upcoming hotel integration, CEO Chesky confirmed that the company is planning to give travelers the option to book a wide variety of hotel options within the Airbnb app, including boutique hotels, star-class hotel chains, and independent hotels.

The hotel booking market adds a massive new opportunity for Airbnb. According to Bernstein analysts, the hotel booking market is approximately 9 times bigger than the short-term rentals market. CEO Chesky has already discussed how travelers use different apps to book hotels when they can't find something suitable on Airbnb, so the company is setting up the stage to keep these travelers within their ecosystem by integrating hotel booking into the app. I believe this will be one of the biggest revenue growth drivers in the next 2 years. For this reason, when Airbnb reports Q3 earnings, I will be paying close attention to management commentary about how these integration plans are moving forward.

In the long term (think of 3+years), the services segment could turn out to be a massive growth driver for Airbnb if the expansion strategy is executed to perfection. Airbnb's goal is to set up the services business as a standalone unit where a traveler does not necessarily have to book an Airbnb stay to avail these services. Last May, the company launched 10 different categories of services including chefs, photography, and spa treatments. In Q3 commentary, the management is likely to discuss the initial market response to these services. During the Q2 earnings call, the management revealed some promising numbers such as a 4.9-star rating for new offerings but the services business had just launched back then. Maintaining a similar level of positive ratings during Q3 should be considered a massive green flag for the future of this segment.

Takeaway

I am looking forward to Airbnb's Q3 earnings release as I believe management commentary (both in the shareholder letter and during the earnings call) will be full of interesting data points that paint a good picture of the company's growth potential. Without a reacceleration in revenue growth, I believe ABNB stock will continue to deliver lackluster returns as an expansion in valuation multiples cannot be expected just because the company is turning into a cash-flow machine. Given the valuation risks faced by the company, I am maintaining my neutral stance on ABNB ahead of the Q3 earnings print, but I may turn bullish even at these prices if the company gives me reason to be optimistic about the probability of an acceleration in growth in the next few quarters.

data.title: Moody's: AI Can Create A Good Opportunity
data.description:
This is the first time I have written about Moody's Corporation (MCO).

Honestly, Moody's seems to me to be one of the best companies in the world, although this does not necessarily mean that it is also a great investment, price plays a fundamental role here.

In this article I will introduce how Moody's business works, so that in this way, we can better understand their latest Q3 earnings, as I think they asked very good questions at the conference call that can even be applied to other companies in the market, such as MSCI Inc. (MSCI).

Business Model

Moody's has two business segments.

1. Moody's Investors Services (MIS): Ratings (4.6% CAGR and 54% of sales).

2. Moody's Analytics (MA): software with data (12.7% CAGR and 46% of sales).

This image shows the annual evolution in sales and operating profit of each of the segments, as well as their compound annual growth rates, their share of the company's sales and operating profit, and finally, the percentage of total recurring sales and their geographical distribution.

It is quite interesting to see how Moody's has been increasing its percentage of recurring sales over the total. Things like this tend to please the market, which ends up being rewarded with re-ratings. This increase in recurring sales should soften the company's total sales because, as we will see below, the ratings segment can be somewhat cyclical.

There are two main reasons for this, which we will look at in more detail later.

1. The zero capacity for capital reinvestment on the Ratings side.

2. The acquisitions made in Analytics in recent years.

In 2022, there was a significant increase in the Analytics segment, from 39% to 51% of sales. This is due to a major acquisition in this segment. On the capital allocation side we will see how they have done several of these in recent years.

In any case, the 70% EBIT margin of MIS vs. 31% of MA (although also expanding) means that ratings represent 54% of sales but 70% of EBIT.

Moody's Investors Services (MIS)

Moody's ratings are divided into several types depending on the type of issuer, although corporate (company) bonds clearly predominate. More than 33,000 companies issued bonds with Moody's last year.

The graph clearly shows how it was not until the MAR '25 quarter that the previous high of MAR '21, when rates were close to 0, was exceeded. From 2021 to the end of 2022, you can see how each quarter they were getting less sales than in the previous quarter, the result of declines in issuance volumes due to the abrupt and massive rise in interest rates that was experienced in 2022.

In general, debt tends to be issued in what are called "issuance waves", but every wave generates a subsequent undertow, which we will see in the "refinancing wall" part.

The good thing about credit ratings is that companies tend to use more than one rating provider for the same issue, so we can say that the services of Moody's and S&P Global Inc. (SPGI) are not mutually exclusive.

The summary of this segment is that it is an oligopoly with 70% margins in a non-exclusive market.

Moody's Analytics (MA)

Moody's Analytics offers a wide range of risk-related data and analytical content, including credit research, quantitative credit ratings, economic research, business intelligence, know-your-customer tools, commercial real estate data, training services, ESG and risk management software for financial institutions.

Debt investors are looking for analytics to understand risks such as credit and counterparty risk. Moody's offers tools that predict the probability of default and provide real-time ratings, as well as early warnings and historical data going back to the 1970s. All of this allows for accurate debt pricing and valuation.

And in some cases, this credit data can have a history of up to 100 years, something irreplicable for any new competitor.

In any case, this is a much more highly competitive segment, which we see tending to grow by acquisitions. Estimates here are less reliable, but we should continue to have a slight margin expansion while the company's percentage of recurring sales increases.

The last decline in the percentage of recurring sales was because the ratings segment (less recurring) grew by 33% last year, compared to 7.8% growth in Analytics.

Capital Allocation

Moody's has made several acquisitions over the past two decades.

To reduce the cyclicality of the ratings business, management decided in 2007-2008 to create Moody's Analytics, using data from the ratings business to build the subscription model mentioned above.

Since then, they have expanded the scale and scope of this business through a series of acquisitions. In 2017 they bought Bureau van Dijk for about $3.5 billion, gaining the Orbis database of information on private companies and M&A deals. In 2018 they acquired REIS, which provides commercial real estate data.

In 2019 they incorporated ESG data, in 2020 they bought a KYC (know your customer) and money laundering prevention suite for about $700 million, and in 2021 they made their last major acquisition: RMS (Risk Management Solutions) for about $2 billion, specializing in services for the property and casualty (P&C) insurance industry.

All of these acquisitions are directly related to the Moody's Analytics segment, although, as mentioned above, half of this segment is more or less directly related to the ratings side, which has little reinvestment capacity.

On the other hand, and rather symbolically, the ratings segment has these holdings: the minority stake in Malaysian Rating Corp. Berhad and its acquisition of Korea Investors Service.

If we look at what Moody's dedicates to the large amount of FCF it generates, we have the following data.

46% of FCF has gone to buybacks and 26% to dividends. Neither are they the best at repurchasing, although they have had some good timing, but there is no pattern of excellence as there is in other companies.

As we have already mentioned, if not for acquisitions, the reinvestment rate is low (15% generally), although in the last two years CAPEX has increased, mainly in the Analytics segment, investing in technology and internal process improvements. It already represents 4.5% of the company's sales, which seems to us a certainly high figure for something that is a priority and should have a CAPEX close to 0. They have been doing this for 3 years and when they return to more normal figures (3% of sales), it could be a good leap for FCF.

Q3 Earnings

These were Moody's results. They presented a beat/beat and raise.

At first glance, the truth is that the results are very good. Sales are reaccelerating significantly, especially in the ratings part (MIS), which last quarter did -0.5%, this quarter they have achieved +12%.

In addition, with margins of 70% vs. 31% in the Analytics segment, EPS has grown at an incredible 22%. However, impeccable management of operating expenses has played a key role in this margin increase. They are up 1% vs. +11% in sales.

Recurring revenues, which represent 96% of Moody's Analytics (MA) total revenues, grew by 11% on a reported basis and 8% on an organic and constant exchange rate basis. Transaction revenues declined 19%, reflecting MA's continued strategic shift to subscription-based solutions. The good news is that recurrence on the Ratings side is already 69% as well.

All this data is very good overall, but I feel like talking about the Q3 results to link directly to the next section on risks, as I think they did a brilliant exposition of them in the call.

Risks

Although the stock now seems to be suffering from a possible AI risk on the Analytics side, we will see how that risk is quite unlikely.

For example, large US banks are incorporating their models and data into internal AI-based workflows. In fact, they signed a $3 million-plus contract with a Tier 1 bank in the U.S., which will use their tools to automate credit reports and deploy early warning systems in real estate portfolios.

Its AI strategy has several layers. The first is an internal platform that allows all employees to build AI agents to redesign processes and gain productivity. Added to this is their "AI Studio Factory," focused on developing agentic products (basically, intelligent agents that use their own data and APIs).

I also don't see the risk of regulation as very likely. I mean, sure at some point it will be tried, but if they are doing better than in the 2008 crisis, it is not difficult and hopefully they have learned the lesson, their Ratings system is something that works well globally; I don't see the incentives or the way to change that.

The other major risk is, directly, already something almost impossible and would put an end to the thesis of gold and Bitcoin, a deleveraging and good economic and budgeting, globally. A utopia. Although a period like this was lived from WWII to 1970.

Half related to this, however, is the risk of the growth of private markets.

When a company uses the private credit market, it accesses financing through private loans, does not issue public bonds and, therefore, does not need a credit rating. In these cases, institutional investors conduct their own risk analysis without resorting to agencies such as Moody's. This means that, as the company's credit rating increases, it will be able to make its own risk analysis.

This means that, as private credit gains ground, the volume of government debt requiring a rating decreases, potentially reducing Moody's core business. CEO Robert Fauber himself explained that the alliance with MSCI stems precisely from the need to offer an independent assessment of private credit risk. It seeks to add value from another angle: helping investors to understand and compare risk with a "trusted third party" view.

Although on the call they commented that they are starting to see some flow back from private credit into the public markets, mainly because coupons in the public market are significantly cheaper than private financing.

While not an immediate threat, it is a gradual and sustained pressure on their traditional revenue model.

Valuation

This valuation method effectively combines a sort of multiples-based valuation, the minimum required rates of return for the stock, and the total return shareholders can achieve in the form of dividends and share buybacks.

Using 2024 FCF as a starting point, I believe that both of Moody's segments can grow at high single-digit rates. The MIS segment is driven by refinancing wall volumes and annual price increases in the order of 4% and the MA segment, I believe, can have organic growths of 5% plus a few extra points inorganically. With the use of AI these companies are becoming much more efficient businesses with the ability to increase margins. So, I think FCF will be able to grow at rates of 12% in a base case.

If we assume an exit multiple of 30x and discount the future value at a minimum required internal rate of return of 12%, factoring in projected dividends and the estimated stock price in 2029, we calculate a fair value of $460 per share. This price would ensure achieving the minimum 12% return over the next 5 years if these assumptions hold.

For all these reasons, I rate the stock as a hold, as it is currently trading at 490$.

Conclusion

Moody's strikes me as a fantastic business, which the market may be unfairly penalizing because of ill-founded fears around AI in its Moody's Analytics segment.

This could create buying opportunities in the company that could benefit long-term investors who understand the business well. While I have not yet added it to the portfolio, it is a company I am following very closely.

data.title: Bank Of Canada Cuts Rate To 2.25% In Second Straight Drop
data.description:
The Bank of Canada cut its key interest rate by 25 basis points to 2.25%. The central bank has also signaled it will likely pause any further rate cuts for the remainder of the year. Francis Fong, Senior Economist with TD Bank Group, speaks with MoneyTalk’s Anthony Okolie about the decision and outlook for the Canadian economy.

Transcript

Anthony Okolie: As widely expected, the Bank of Canada lowered its key rate a quarter point to 2.25%. Joining me now to discuss the latest decision is Francis Fong, Senior Economist with TD Bank Group.

And Francis, what's your reaction to the decision? Any surprises here?

Francis Fong: Yeah, first of all, thanks for having me back, Anthony. Always great to be here. So no surprises in this decision. I think this was a widely expected rate cut. If we look at where the growth picture has come in, where the inflation data has come in, where the unemployment rate or the employment data has come in, a lot of it has pointed to additional space for the bank to lower rates and support that overall economy. We've seen quite a lot of weakness in areas like exports, investment, whereas we've seen maybe a bit of resilience on the consumer spending side, but enough so that the Bank could provide that additional cut. So yeah, no surprises there.

Anthony Okolie: Now, the big question is, does this latest cut mark the end of the Bank of Canada's easing cycle?

Francis Fong: Yeah, and I think this sort of follows where the economic profile is going to be in the next few quarters. We do anticipate that second-quarter growth, which was quite weak in a lot of key areas. We do expect that to be the bottom in growth. We're already seeing the kind of Q3 growth picture's come back a little bit, though perhaps not as strong as some would like. And so that should provide some basis for the Bank of Canada to remain on hold.

I mean, at 2.25%, we're already talking about where the Bank of Canada sort of finds the neutral rate. And so I believe the bank is quite comfortable where they are. And they actually did communicate that, so long as the economy progresses how they envision it-- and so far, the data is of lining up with that-- this is likely where they're going to keep the floor. So they've already choreographed that well. So absent any kind of surprise on the downside or, in fact, the upside, this is likely where we're going to see rates for the medium term.

Anthony Okolie: I think one area that there's a lot of uncertainty right now remains tariffs and the lack of a deal between the US and Canada. Now, big question-- what happens if we don't reach a deal, and what are the implications for monetary policy?

Francis Fong: That's a great question, Anthony. And I think this is obviously where there is quite a lot of uncertainty because if you read the headlines, and you read the headlines alone, it will give you the impression that things are in a very dire state. Obviously, we just sort of had a potential trade deal fall through, according to Prime Minister Carney. And so that kind of leaves a lot of folks with a lot of uncertainty. I think if you dig into the Bank of Canada's Monetary Policy Report and even in our own forecast, we do embed an actual tariff assumption in those forecasts. Bank of Canada, for example, has an average tariff rate of about 6%, as of their October Monetary Policy Report. That is a far cry from the big double-digit numbers that, for example, Trump is talking about and things of that nature. That's the actual one that we see.

But on the same token, that is not felt evenly across the country. That 6% is really a reflection of the much higher tariff rate we're seeing on steel and aluminum, on non-CUSMA compliant autos, softwood lumber, things of that nature. So we do see some higher sectoral impacts, whereas the actual average tariff rate is quite modest.

So what that means is there's still going to be uncertainty going forward because that 6% tariff rate is being felt in some parts of the economy. So we're still hoping for that deal to sort of remove that sort of uncertainty. But if no trade deal takes place, we're sort of where we are today, which is sort of a major headwind. But we're still seeing some resilience behind the scenes in areas that are not so hard hit.

Anthony Okolie: Alright, now, we also have the upcoming federal budget soon. What are your thoughts on that? And what implications, if any, will that have on Bank of Canada policy going forward?

Francis Fong: So I mentioned the neutral rate a little bit earlier. I think that's really where we're going to see the impact of where the Bank of Canada thinks the Canadian economy is going to be long term because all the conversations around the federal budget, everything that Mark Carney is talking about right now, is around, how do we reorient the Canadian economy away from a trading partner, a primary trading partner, that is perhaps less reliable than it has been in the past.

Anthony Okolie: So how do we create those new trade routes in between the country or within the country and, of course, across the Pacific and across the Atlantic? That requires huge investments in everything from trade infrastructure, transportation infrastructure, making our firms more competitive in those markets that previously we haven't really had to compete in up until now. So what does that picture look like?

Francis Fong: So where we're looking for more clarity and more guidance is what are those investments that we're going to make. Obviously, we're already hearing things about major projects and things of that nature. But beyond that, how are we establishing ourselves in those markets, and will it work? And of course, that has implications for what the trend rate of the overnight rate will look like. And so there's implications there. But in the short term, it's likely not going to have too, too much of an impact.

Anthony Okolie: Alright, so given this latest decision, how do you expect the loonie to perform going forward?

Francis Fong: So I think the narrative around loonie has been difficult to parse. Up to or sort of over the last year, we've really seen the Canadian dollar be part of this broader narrative around US dollar weakness across many of its trading partners. And that's driven a lot of the dynamics over the last year or so. Lately, I think we've seen more divergence among advanced economies relative to the US dollar, where it's short-rate differentials. So given that the Canadian economy has performed, I think, relatively weaker than a lot of our advanced counterparts, and that's obviously, especially true given our reliance on the US, there's been some more pronounced weakness relative to some others.

But we do anticipate that, as the economic profile improves over time, and we start to see that growth picture get a little better, we're already seeing some upside surprises on the employment side, on the inflation side. All of that, I think, will contribute to some US-- sorry, some Canadian dollar strengthening. And we do anticipate it to strengthen from here to about $0.75, sort of towards late next year and through our medium-term forecast horizon.

Anthony Okolie: Now, you talked about inflation. You talked about jobs. Are there any things, key reports that you'll be watching closely to get a sense of how the Canadian economy will perform over the longer term?

Francis Fong: I mean, there's-- that's a complicated question. There's a lot of data we're looking at. Obviously, growth, inflation, and employment, the obvious ones that we'll be keeping an eye on because there's been quite a bit of volatility, driven, no doubt, by the uncertainty that firms and individuals are facing. But on top of that, we're really going to be looking at the political side, what's coming out of this budget, how does that set us up long term.

And we're going to be looking at a lot of individual components of GDP. For example, how does the trade picture improve? We saw a massive decline in real exports, particular, 32% annualized reduction in real goods exports. How does that trade picture improve? All of that, I think, contributes to how is the Canadian economy staying resilient in the face of this new threat, and how do we evolve going forward, so lots of data that we're keeping an eye on.

Anthony Okolie: Francis, thanks for your time.

Francis Fong: Always a pleasure, Anthony.

Original Post

data.title: Taylor Morrison Home Corporation Deserves An Upgrade
data.description:
As a big fan of the home building industry, one company that continues to interest me is Taylor Morrison Home Corporation (TMHC). With a market capitalization of $6.19 billion as of this writing, and a good track record for growth under its belt, it is certainly an intriguing prospect. On top of this, shares of the business trade on the cheap, and leverage is lower than what we see with most other similar enterprises. Currently, the housing market is undergoing significant stress. And that is something that investors should continue to monitor closely. This is especially true when you consider that firms such as this are finally starting to see some pain from that weakness. But given how cheap shares are, because of its overall financial position, and because my expectation that the long-term picture for the housing industry will eventually improve, I believe that now is actually a great time to upgrade the company from a "Buy" to a "Strong Buy."

A Great Play In Housing

Fundamentally speaking, things are not going exactly great for shareholders of Taylor Morrison Home Corporation. However, the share price of the company has performed exceptionally well in recent years. Admittedly, since I last reaffirmed it as a "Buy" candidate in June of this year, the stock has underperformed the market, rising just 5.4% while the S&P 500 is up 11.6%. But since I originally rated it a "Buy" in January 2022, the stock has significantly outperformed the market, skyrocketing 103.9% while the market is up only 52.9%.

The recent underperformance by the company seems to be tied to weakness in the housing market. In the image above, you can see how the median price of a new home sold has been on the decline for a few years now. This is because of inflationary pressures and high-interest rates aimed at combating them. Unfortunately, because of the government shutdown, we don't have the most up-to-date data here. But we do know that, as of August, of this year, the number of housing completions was 8.4% lower than it was a year earlier. The number of housing starts was down 6%, while building permits were down 11.1%. As I have written about in other articles, such as here and here, I firmly believe that the U.S. economy is barreling toward a recession. So in the short term, I fully expect these conditions to worsen.

Because of the time lag between when market conditions change and when homebuilders ultimately deliver their homes, we are just now seeing some of the weakness that Taylor Morrison Home Corporation was destined to see. In the chart above, you can see financial results for the third quarter of the 2025 fiscal year compared to the same time last year. You can also see results for the first nine months of this year compared to the same time last year.

During the most recent quarter, revenue for the company came in at just under $2.10 billion. That's down from the $2.12 billion that the company reported a year earlier. This was driven by a decline in the number of homes closed from 3,394 to 3,324, which more than offset a rise in the average price of a home from $598,000 last year to $602,000 this year. However, for the first nine months of this year in its entirety, the number of homes closed was up, while the average price was down slightly. The chart above illustrates this. And that, clearly, helped to push revenue for the first nine months of this year up compared to the same time last year.

This recent decrease in sales had a deleterious impact on the company's bottom line. Net income contracted from $251.1 million to $201.4 million. But that's not all. While operating cash flow did skyrocket from $135.9 million to $219.6 million, we saw this metric, adjusted for changes in working capital, fall from $264.7 million to $257 million. Meanwhile, EBITDA for the company contracted from $379.2 million to $333.1 million. Although net profits are down for this year in its entirety, all other cash flow metrics for the company have improved, which means that the problems seen in the most recent quarter are new. In fact, management, while acknowledging broader economic conditions that have delayed the purchase of homes, mentioned that the company has been offering even greater incentives and discounts to drive buying activity.

These discounts have been reflected in net new orders for the institution. In the most recent quarter, the company saw net new orders amounting to 2,468 homes. That's down 12.8% from the 2,830 homes ordered a year earlier. At the same time as this occurred, the average price of a home ordered contracted from $587,000 to $567,000. Unlike what we saw in revenue, this is not a new trend. In fact, as the chart above illustrates, net new orders and average prices for new homes ordered have both contracted year over year for the first nine months of 2025 compared to the same time of 2024. The company is also seeing a rise in its cancellation rate, with an increase from 9.3% in the third quarter of last year to 15.4% this year. This is evidence that the buyers of its homes are becoming increasingly pressured by difficult market conditions.

In the chart above, you can see the impact that prior large home deliveries, and weaker net new orders, have had on the company's backlog. The number of homes in its backlog came in at only 3,605 homes in the third quarter of this year. That's an astounding decline of 36.7% compared to the 5,692 homes in backlog a year earlier. And at the same time, as the company has pushed out more of the higher-priced homes and brought in more of the lower-priced ones, the average price of a home in backlog dropped from $673,000 to $648,000.

This makes it difficult to know what the future holds. If we do project out based on the results that we have seen already for this year, we would get net profits of about $838.6 million, adjusted operating cash flow of $1.09 billion, and EBITDA of $1.40 billion. With these estimates, we can see in the chart above how shares of the company are currently valued. Obviously, this does not capture the prospect of additional weakening in the market. But considering how cheap the stock is, even with the picture worsening, shares could still be quite appealing. This is true not only on an absolute basis, but relative to other similar firms as well. In the table below, I stacked Taylor Morrison Home Corporation up against five other similar enterprises. On a price-to-earnings basis, two of the firms are cheaper than it is, while another is tied with it. But when it comes to the other two valuation approaches, our prospect is the cheapest of the group.

Company Price / Earnings Price / Operating Cash Flow EV / EBITDA
Taylor Morrison Home Corporation 7.4 5.7 5.7
Hovnanian Enterprises (HOV) 6.3 6.4 8.1
Meritage Homes (MTH) 6.2 19.1 7.5
Century Communities (CCS) 7.4 13.1 11.9
Beazer Homes USA (BZH) 10.7 25.9 20.1
KB Home (KBH) 8.8 11.4 8.5

Another advantage that Taylor Morrison Home Corporation has over most of its competitors is leverage. The firm has net debt of only $1.82 billion right now. In the chart below, you can see that this translates to a net leverage ratio of 1.30. That's below four of the five institutions that I stacked it up against. In fact, I would argue that it is substantially lower than these other four players. That provides the company additional flexibility and optionality, especially in a down market. So I don't have any concern about the long-term viability of the business.

In the short run, I do remain concerned about market conditions. According to one source, the newest tariffs imposed by the Trump Administration will raise the cost of the average home by $8,900. And that does not even factor in any potential ramifications from the newest 10% tariff imposed on Canada by the United States. Considering that Canada supplies about 24% of US softwood lumber consumption for the United States, and that this works out to as much as 85% of all U.S. softwood lumber imports, we could have additional costs stemming from this decision. But the good news is that, earlier this year, Zillow (Z) estimated that there exists a housing deficit of 4.7 million homes nationwide. This is actually a record high despite a five-year construction boom.

For several years now, the United States has been underbuilding. So even with a surge of construction activity, the preexisting shortage and a continued growth of the U.S. population caused this shortage to balloon. At some point, the combination of additional population growth and some of the 8.1 million families that are now sharing homes with non-relatives, will eventually hit a breaking point and push buying activity up, but perhaps only after a recession and a big decline in interest rates. When that does happen, Taylor Morrison Home Corporation will be in a prime position to benefit.

Takeaway

Based on all the data currently available, I still believe that while market conditions could worsen in the near term, Taylor Morrison Home Corporation is in a good spot. The firm is cheap, and the overall risk profile of it is low. When you consider long-term trends, this bodes well for shareholders. So at the end of the day, I firmly believe that increasing my rating from a "Buy" to a "Strong Buy" makes sense.

data.title: Verisk Analytics: Improving, Not Yet Compelling After Another Deal And Pullback
data.description:
In July, I called shares of Verisk Analytics (VRSK) too expensive following its strategic direction of focus. This followed the divestment of non-core business activities in the years before. Ever since, shares have lost about 30% in the time frame of a quarter, while the market at large has been trading fairly stable.

This has certainly improved appeal, as the company announced an interesting acquisition as well. Right now, valuations have been compressed quite a bit, but still mark a substantial premium to the overall market, although that I am inclined to buy the dip below the $200 mark.

Data Analytics Play

Verisk is a provider of key data analytics functions in the global insurance industry, which in itself includes various segments like life & annuity, auto, property, casualty, weather events, etc.

Its role is that of strategic data analytics and technology partner in order to provide insights to its client base, which use such data for underwriting and claims. These insights allow them to make more informed decisions, which is key given the amounts involved with such underwriting.

Verisk generates about $3 billion in sales from providing such services with EBITDA margins exceeding 50% of sales, an impressive result for a completely focused business with retention rates close to 100%. Some 70% of its sales are generated by underwriting solutions, with the remainder of revenues coming from claim solutions. In all, some 80% of sales are generated in North America, with the remainder of revenues generated abroad.

Becoming A Focused Business

Up to a couple of years ago, the company has a smaller energy segment and financial service industry activity as well, yet it has divested these assets in recent years. The completely focused business posted a 7% increase in sales, both in 2023 and 2024, with revenues last year reported up to nearly $2.9 billion. The company reported EBITDA near $1.6 billion, translating into truly remarkable margins, with adjusted earnings reported at $6.64 per share.

For the year 2025, the company initially saw sales up to a midpoint of $3.05 billion, with adjusted earnings seen a couple pennies short of the $7 per share mark. Trading at $303 in July, as the company was awarded a $45 billion enterprise valuation, equal to 15 times sales, valuing equity at a mid-forty times earnings multiple.

That was not about to change following a $162 million bolt-on deal announced for SuranceBay over the summer, and while the performance of the business was impressive, an earnings yield in the low 2s was simply too low to see appeal.

Coming Down

Since the summer, share of Verisk have seen quite a setback, now trading down 20% to $208 per share, levels first seen in the summer of 2023.

The fall started by the end of July, when the company announced both second quarter results, and announced a substantial acquisition. Second quarter sales were up 8% in a steady fashion to $773 million. The company hiked the midpoint of the sales guidance to $3.11 billion, aided by a weaker dollar, but at the same time trimmed the full year earnings guidance by five cents to a midpoint of $6.90 per share.

Net debt stood at $2.6 billion as 140 million shares outstanding make for a $34.0 billion equity valuation and $36.6 billion enterprise valuation. This reduces sales multiples to about 12 times, with earnings trading at a 35 times multiple.

At the same time, Verisk announced a substantial $2.35 billion purchase of AccuLynx, with the company being a leading SAAS platform which provides end-to-end management workflows for residential property contractors. The company really focuses on all information in such projects, while providing key links between insurers, contractors, suppliers and third party administrators.

The purchase does not come cheap. The company, which has been founded in 2018, generates about $150 million in annual sales. This suggests that a premium 15 times sales multiple has been paid, although that its sales are seen up mid-to double-digits. The 55% EBITDA margins are in line with margins reported by Verisk itself. This will double net debt essentially to $5 billion, still manageable, for a net leverage ratio in the mid to-higher 2s.

Investors gotten a bit spooked as shares fell by another 10% towards the end of October, when Verisk reported a ¨mere¨ 5.5% increase in organic constant currency sales for the third quarter. Worse, slower growth came amidst margin pressure as well, with adjusted earnings up just 3% to $1.72 per share. While the company maintains its full year $6.80-$7.00 adjusted earnings per share outlook, the full year sales outlook has been trimmed by $40-$50 million here, trending closer to the original outlook.

This continued fall in the share price made that earnings multiples compressed further to 30 times, which is a lot more compelling than this summer, but still rather demanding.

And Now?

With the deal for AccuLynx taking place at a substantial premium, it is easy to become a bit more cautious, also as organic growth is slowing down. High valuations and a subsequent 30% pullback have reduced earnings multiples from the mid-forties to thirty times. This has pushed up the earnings yield from a low 2% to the low 3s%, which is compelling, but still demanding.

Verisk is a very strong business, one which I have great admiration for, as the move has certainly improved appeal a great deal. The question is if current multiples in the low-thirties are compelling enough, now also given the leveraged up balance sheet, as frankly I need a bigger margin of safety here.

Hence, I am watching this development unfold with great interest, looking to get involved at levels towards below $200 mark. I fully recognize the risk that I might not see such levels as the market rightfully awards premium multiple to a premium business for a long time already, with the risk-reward gradually becoming more balanced here.

data.title: Metsera Becomes The Prize In Obesity's Biggest Bidding War
data.description:
Overview

Metsera, Inc. (MTSR) finds itself in an all-out bidding war between an established obesity treatment giant, Novo Nordisk (NVO), and a contender in Pfizer (PFE).

Metsera IPO’d earlier this year. The company is advancing a pipeline of “next-generation Nutrient Stimulated Hormone targets.”

Its lead program, MET-097i (inj.), is a fully-biased, ultra-long-acting GLP-1 RA that aims for once-monthly administration with no titration regimen (Phase 2). Metsera is also testing MET-097i with MET-233i (inj.), an ultra-long-acting amylin analog, in a Phase 1 trial. Beyond injectables, Metsera boasts ultra-long-acting oral GLP-1 peptides that aim for injectable-like efficacy at lower doses to curtail manufacturing and scaling hurdles.

In addition to its investigational assets, Metsera is grounded on its platform: HALO (lipidation), MOMENTUM (oral delivery), and MINT (a library of 20,000 NuSH analogs from two decades of work).

So, it’s easy to see why big pharmaceutical companies are, figuratively speaking, fighting over it.

It all started when Metsera signed a deal with Pfizer on September 22, 2025, for $47.50 cash plus $22.50 CVR (up to ~$7.3 billion). Earlier today, Novo Nordisk launched an unsolicited bid valuing Metsera up to ~$9 billion. Immediately following, Pfizer fired back, calling Novo Nordisk’s bid “unprecedented,” “reckless,” and “in violation of law.” Metsera then declared Novo Nordisk’s proposal as “superior.”

Following the hoopla, Metsera’s stock climbed ~20% to ~$63.50 (intraday).

The article that follows takes a closer look at the developments and uncovers what’s ahead for Metsera investors.

What's In It For Metsera

First, let’s begin by laying out the two deals side-by-side.

Item

Pfizer (signed merger)

Novo Nordisk (unsolicited; deemed “Superior”)

Headline value (max)

Up to $70.00/share

Up to $77.75/share

Up-front cash to holders

$47.50/share at closing

Two-step: NVO pays $56.50/share to MTSR; MTSR issues NVO 50% non-voting preferred; same day, MTSR declares a $56.50/share cash dividend, paid ~10 days later

Contingent value right (CVR)

Up to $22.50/share tied to specified dev./approval milestones

Up to $21.25/share CVR with milestones “substantially similar” to Pfizer CVR

Board stance

The board still recommends approving the Pfizer merger

The board has delivered a “Superior Proposal” notice to Pfizer

Match/negotiation window

4 business days for Pfizer to negotiate terms so Novo no longer “Superior,” although Pfizer believes Metsera had no right to deliver “Superior” notice

With this context, Metsera’s current price of ~$63.50 is a risk-adjusted, time-discounted price across scenarios. The three most likely scenarios are as follows:

  • Pfizer ups/matches and wins (60-70% likely).

  • Novo signs and ultimately pays up to $77.75 (25-35%).

  • Break (≤5%).

Why is Metsera’s stock 20% higher today? For starters, the max consideration rose ~11%. Moreover, a real rival bid and “Superior” designation increase the probability that some deal closes. Lastly, there’s now credible overbid/match potential from Pfizer. Essentially, the market is pricing in a modestly sweetened deal by Pfizer.

While existing Metsera investors are “sitting pretty,” I don’t see much opportunity for “arbitrage” for prospective investors, especially as the process may drag (Pfizer disputes “Superior” notice; Novo Nordisk faces higher antitrust scrutiny).

Metsera appears structurally incentivized to close with Pfizer. The signed Pfizer agreement is still the governing deal; there may be a credible litigation threat if Metsera pivots to Novo Nordisk, and there is antitrust asymmetry (Novo Nordisk’s obesity dominance with Wegovy). Also, don’t underestimate the weight Boards give to speed and certainty of closure. So, this may not be the case of “highest bidder wins.”

What's In It For Pfizer

The acquisition would reignite Pfizer’s obesity pipeline, which is noticeably barren following the danuglipron failure. Given the massive size of the obesity treatment market (near-term estimates are as high as $100 billion), Pfizer is almost obligated to pay up.

Novo Nordisk’s bid follows Phase 2b data for Metsera’s MET-097i (monthly), released just days after the Pfizer deal.

As a fully biased mono-agonist, MET-097i achieved dual-agonist-like weight loss of 14.1% at 28 weeks in VESPER-1, with only 2.9% study discontinuation. In VESPER-3, with two titration steps to the highest dose evaluated, we saw potentially class-leading tolerability with a placebo-like frequency of diarrhea, and a risk difference from placebo of 13% for nausea, and 11% for vomiting. Based on these data, MET-097i is advancing into Phase 3 clinical trials, accelerating its development as the foundational peptide for Metsera’s combination, oral, and prodrug programs.

For context, Novo Nordisk’s Wegovy (weekly) inspired ~14.9% mean weight loss at 68 weeks (STEP-1) with discontinuation for AEs at 6.8%. Eli Lilly’s (LLY) Zepbound caused ~20-21% mean weight loss at 72 weeks (SURMOUNT-1; H2H vs. Wegovy also superior) with discontinuation AEs ~6%.

So, both Wegovy and Zepbound require once-weekly dosing with multistep titration to mitigate GI AEs. MET-097i is dosed monthly with an encouraging GI AE profile. Should MET-097i confer Wegovy-like efficacy (possibly greater) and low discontinuation in Phase 3, it could have a clear path towards becoming an obesity blockbuster.

What's In It For Novo Nordisk

Novo Nordisk’s interest signals that it is bracing for margin/price pressure in the GLP-1 world. Wegovy will not be a blockbuster forever. The onus in biopharma is the need for continuous innovation. Acquiring Metsera delivers a clean, vertically integrated “next-gen” pipeline (amylin/GLP-1 combos) to renew its leadership.

That being said, Novo Nordisk’s obesity pipeline is already dense. However, Metsera now has a late-stage, titration-light, GLP-1 backbone. Moreover, Novo’s combo approach is weekly (CagriSema; amycretin weekly and oral). Whereas, Metsera’s co-formulated GLP-1 + amylin is dosed monthly. Lastly, Metsera’s MOMENTUM platform addresses the API/COGS bottleneck that Novo Nordisk’s oral semaglutide (approval pending in obesity) will certainly suffer from.

Final Thoughts

To wrap up, Novo Nordisk’s unsolicited bid for Metsera adds both uncertainty and further upside potential for the latter’s shareholders. However, this is already priced in, so any arbitrage potential appears muted. As such, Metsera investors will benefit from staying put until this works itself out (“Hold” rating).

For Pfizer, its press release today, in my view, reeks of desperation. It should remain focused on closing the deal, rather than publicly antagonizing its target.
