Obviously, both sides (Metsera & Pfizer) are saying different things about what is and isn’t allowed (in terms of other deals). Without the details on my desk, I can only speculate. What I do know is that Pfizer needs Metsera more than anyone else.

Clearly, Novo Nordisk also needs Metsera. Although Wegovy remains a monster in its own right, it is slowly losing ground to Zepbound, and the obesity treatment market in just 3–4 years from now will be very different. To put it simply, Novo Nordisk is at risk of losing its stronghold in obesity, which is why its stock trades the way it does (-55% in the past year).

data.title: VF Corp.: Turnaround Increasingly Distant And Uncertain
data.description:
V.F. Corp. (VFC) is now two years into a turnaround under CEO Bracken Darrell. I've been long the stock for much of this time, and have written bullish articles on SA in March 2024 and March 2025, arguing that the market has been too impatient with management's strategy. After another several quarters of operating results in 2025, I'm writing with an update in which I will put this week's results in a slightly longer perspective, and to explain why I have decided to throw in the towel and sell my shares.

I think bulls and bears are both only capturing part of the story here. VF's turnaround is working, especially on the operational side (turning around the trajectory of Vans is proving harder than expected), but a combination of inherent difficulties and tariffs is going to mean that the turnaround will take longer than initially expected. Hence, my question: how long are you willing to wait?

Recent Financials

Over the last four quarters, VF management has made measurable progress on improving the company's financial profile. They quickly achieved the first $300 million in cost savings and announced another $500-$600 million more over the next three years. Gross margins have stabilized and operating margins have improved significantly. Meanwhile, the sales of Supreme and now, more recently, Dickie's have brought down debt by almost 50% from $5.7 billion when Darrell began to probably around $2.9 billion after the Dickie's sale is completed. This has not yet led to any sustained drop in interest expenses, but it is definitely a move in the right direction.

In the latest quarter's call, management explained that if they exclude Dickie's, about 70% of the company's brands by revenue are now growing. That is great news, and speaks to the real strength of North Face and Timberland especially. But Vans, the largest brand, continues to suffer. Over the last four quarters, Vans revenue has post YOY drops of -8%, -20%, -15%, and -11%, respectively. Especially in the middle two quarters, management attributed a big part of the drop to store closures in North America. They have basically said that, excluding their own deliberate rebalancing, the drops have been stable in the high single digits. I don't take this as necessarily a negative sign, but it offers us no real evidence of progress on the turnaround.

Business Developments

On the earnings calls, Darrell remains exceptionally optimistic and positive about the behind-the-scenes changes going on within the management of VF's brands, especially Vans. The company has been trying to "premiumize" the brand more, and has gotten positive feedback on their Warped Tour and Instagram marketing campaigns.

But compared with the report in 2024 that SEO results were really improving in Europe, these comments are much less quantitatively solid and rigorous. I remain generally confident that Darrell's turnaround plan makes sense and will work over time, but the tough reality is that Vans is still losing customers. Management has shifted from providing some hard - if small - evidence of improvement in 2024 to saying that "turnarounds take time" in 2025. In other words, they are no longer providing a clear timeline for the Vans turnaround. Instead, we hear that the CEO is "super confident" that Vans will return to growth (on the Q2 call this week) but also that "I'm going to keep the expectations low for Vans as long as possible, because I want to give her plenty of room to operate" (FY25 Q3 call in January).

I appreciate the optimism and think Darrell's team is being reasonable in moderating expectations and working on the actual business, but investors need to plan accordingly. At this point, there is little reason to expect strong revenue growth in 2026. Consensus estimates are for 1% YOY growth for FY26 (ending in March 2027). That seems conservative to me, but I also see little evidence to support more bullishness.

Management has put on a good face about tariffs, emphasizing their mitigation strategies and diverse sourcing across Southeast Asia and Latin America, but the reality is that they project the tariffs to cost them about $250-$270 million, mostly in 2026, a figure which they have revised upwards from an initial estimate of $150 million. This is made worse by the fact that the brands have (it seems) very little pricing power. As management explained on the Q1 call in July, VF's products have an overall price elasticity of about one, meaning that any increase in prices that they pass on to consumers will be met with a proportional drop in sales volume.

Second, with the business only generating about $400 million in OCF per year over the last two years, this net increase in costs is going to make it much harder to pay down debt, etc. Remember that VF Corp is still paying out about $140 million per year in dividends. So, the tariff costs are going to eat up most of the other cash that the business might have generated to pay down debt and fuel growth.

The stock nosedived this spring when the tariffs were announced, from a recent high of $28 all the way down to below $10. Since then, they have of course recovered along with the broader market. But make no mistake, the tariffs are bad news, made worse by VF's limited cash generation ability and high debt burden. I don't see the tariffs going away anytime soon, and so investors need to accordingly moderate their expectations about the speed of the turnaround.

Outlook for Shares

In the wake of this week's earnings report, as shares slide over 10%, analysts updated their forecasts and price targets. The three most highly-rated analysts according to TipRanks are in perfect disagreement:

  1. Sam Poser (Williams Trading): SELL, price target $10
  2. Adrienne Yih (Barclays): BUY, price target $18

  3. John Kernan (TD Cowen): HOLD, price target $15

Looking at the monthly chart below, We can see how those targets match up with recent price action. Shares have seen very strong support (and insider buying) between $9 and $12, but they've failed to reliably break out about $20 or so. Perhaps the gradual upwards trend of the last few months will be sustained despite the recent sell-off, but I don't see a strong fundamental reason for it at this point.

I remain impressed with the optimism, energy, and successes of VF Corp's turnaround effort. But over the last nine months, there have been two major new headwinds: tariffs and stalling progress at Vans. Over the medium term (say 3-5 years) I remain optimistic about management's ability to revitalize Timberlands, North Face, and Vans, and to stabilize revenue and profitability.

But with shares already trading at over 20x 2026 earnings - a valuation about 20% above the industry average - I think a significant portion of that medium-term improvement is already priced in. In the shorter-term, tariffs, dividends, and revenue declines are going to limit FCF and leave the company's debt levels stubbornly high. It turns out that, as many writers have noted, turnarounds are longer and slower than people usually hope.
